bibl.title: Letter from Harold Leidelin to Henry Rose Carter, March 9, 1915

div1.p: Leidelin claims that he has successfully infected a guinea pig with yellow fever. He hopes to receive U.S. Public Health Service support.

div1.head: Letter from Harold Leidelin to Henry Rose Carter, March 9, 1915
div1.opener:
Telephone 2402 Royal.
THE INCORPORATED
LIVERPOOL SCHOOL OF TROPICAL MEDICINE.
============
March 9th 1915
YELLOW FEVER BUREAU,
UNIVERSITY OF LIVERPOOL.
Dear Dr. Carter,
div1.p: Many thanks for your letter of January 25th.

I shall be very glad indeed if you will send me the epi-
demiological data which you mention. Itn is quite true as you say
that experiments are often more satisfactory than observation, but in
this particular case they would have to be somewhat numerous, a consi-
derable inconvenience in the case of human experiments. In this, as in
many other respects, it would be of the greatest possible importance
if we could always use animal experiments instead. I and several other
investigators are of opinion that we have produced yellow fever in
guinea-pigs and I have recently proposed an experiment in order to
decide whether our animals have really been infected with yellow fever.
I enclose a recently published note of mine, in which I state the
broad outlines of this experiment as I think it should be done.
(As I have received no reprints of this paper, I prefer to send you
at once, instead of waiting, a copy of the Journ. Trop. Med. in which
the paper appeared. I am sending this under separate cover together
with a few reprints of other papers.)

I have put this proposal before the Yellow Fever Commission,
but they have declined it as they are not authorized to undertake
human experiments. It appears to me that it ought not to be difficult
to find volunteers for this experiment considering that several people
2
feel so very certain that I am mistaken. Should the experiment, however,
prove that I am right then we should not only be able to solve the
question of carriers and of mild infections, but we should in all
probability soon possess an effective personal prophylaxis against
yellow fever.

If you consider the matter worth while, I suppose you would
succeed in getting your Public Health Service to undertake the experi-
ments, in which case I should of course be glad if they would make
use of my services, but also otherwise I should be glad to discuss
with you in further detail how the experiments should be conducted.
In order to obtain conclusive results, it would be advisable to
have the matter fully discussed before starting work.

The full reports of works done in West Africa will soon
appear and I suppose the Commission will send you a personal copy.

I trust you are quite well by now and send you my best wishes
for a complete recovery from that very disagreeable disease.
